ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT release site change and more info
ygData.msgSnippet: I haven t tried to compile my application for OS/X, but I think if you follow the instructions for linux, it should compile fine. I can try to create an OS/X

I haven't tried to compile my application for OS/X, but I think if 
you fol=
low the instructions for linux, it should compile fine.

I can try to creat=
e an OS/X binary next time I'm in the lab.

With regards to your question o=
n network order, I think that the 
reason why I don't set it up so my nodes=
 are only evaluated once is 
because it becomes more difficult as you add r=
ecurrent connections.  
It's hard to say if a node that receieves a recurre=
nt connection 
input should also process non-recurrent inputs, should modif=
y its 
current value, or some other behavior.  If the decision is to receiv=
e 
all inputs simultaneously, then you might as well just update the 
whole=
 network for some set number of iterations rather than try to 
model the fl=
ow in a way that might be hard for the network to train 
on.

--- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On Apr 11, 2007, at=
 9:48 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> > I want to mention that Jason put a =
lot of effort in to make this
> > package user-friendly, both from the exec=
utable and source code
> > standpoint.
> 
> I didn't run it (I'd love an OS=
 X binary), but I took at look at  
> Jason's code for a few minutes last n=
ight.  It is one of the 
cleaner  
> NEAT implementations.
> 
> I do have o=
ne question.. is there some reason you guys don't sort  
> your networks so=
 that nodes only need to be updated once?  Network  
> order is easily dete=
rmined via BFS.  Then you just need some "same  
> layer order" heuristic (=
such as lower innovation numbers first).   
> It's a common theme in NEAT i=
mplementations - I assume because 
lots  
> of people used Ken's original c=
ode?  Or am I missing something???
> 
> I plan on digging into the code som=
e more in the next few days.   
> Thanks for publishing it!
> 
> --Steve
>
